definition: Gaya, a Korean confederacy of territorial polities in the Nakdong River basin of southern Korea (42-532 AD)

History of Three Kingdoms (Korean: Samguk Sagi), the oldest extant Korean history, compiled under Kim Busik 金富軾|金富轼[Jin1 Fu4 shi4] in 1145. The three kingdoms are Goguryeo 高句麗|高句丽[Gao1 gou1 li2], Baekje 百濟|百济[Bai3 ji4], Silla 新羅|新罗[Xin1 luo2].
gayageum/Korean 12-stringed zither
Paekche or Baekje (18 BC-660 AD), one of the Korean Three Kingdoms
variant of 高句麗|高句丽[Gao1 gou1 li2]
Asuka Period in Japanese history (538-710 AD)
Magadha, ancient India kingdom reported to be the birthplace of Buddhism

Silla, Korean kingdom 57 BC-935 AD/one of the Korean Three Kingdoms from 1st century AD, defeating its rivals Paikche 百濟|百济[Bai3 ji4] and Koguryo 高句麗|高句丽[Gao1 gou1 li2] around 660 in alliance with Tang China/unified Silla 658-935
variant of 扶餘|扶余 Korean: Buyeo (c. 200 BC-494 AD), ancient kingdom in northeast frontier region of China

Nara period (710-794) in early Japanese history
Yemaek, ancient ethnic group of Manchuria and Korea, precursors of Korean Goguryeo kingdom

name of a state and its people in Shangdong in late Spring and Autumn period
Pu'yo, Korean Buyeo (c. 200 BC-494 AD), ancient kingdom in northeast frontier region of China
